title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" establishes grants for quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families under the Social Security Act. The purpose of this section is to enhance the well-being of children by supporting quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. States seeking grants must submit an application describing these programs. The grant supports home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. A needs assessment will determine the number and quality of programs in the state, as well as the eligible families receiving services. The curr_chunk discusses the sources of funding, gaps in early childhood home visitation, and training activities for programs. It also includes assurances from the State regarding supporting home visitation programs. The State will prioritize serving communities in high need, especially those with low-income families or child maltreatment. 5% of grant funds will be reserved for training and technical assistance for home visitation programs. Coordination and collaboration with other child services will be promoted in supporting home visitation programs. The State will promote coordination and collaboration with other child and family services, health services, income supports, and related assistance for home visitation programs supported by grant funds. Referrals to other programs serving children and families will be provided when appropriate. The State will comply with requirements and cooperate with evaluations. Other information as required by the Secretary will also be provided. The Secretary may require allotments to Indian tribes based on the number of children in the tribe whose families have income below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary shall allot funds to States based on the number of children in families with income below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary allots funds to States based on the number of children in families with income below 200 percent of the poverty line. Any unspent allotments by a State can be reallotted to another State as part of their allotment under this subsection. Beginning in fiscal year 2011, a State must maintain its expenditures for quality home visitation programs for families with young children at 100% of the previous two years' expenditures to meet the requirements for receiving a grant from the Secretary. In fiscal years 2010 and 2011, States must maintain their expenditures for home visitation programs at a certain percentage to receive grants from the Secretary. In fiscal years 2011 and beyond, States must maintain their home visitation program expenditures at 80% for 2011 and 75% for 2012 and subsequent years to be eligible for grants. Eligible expenditures include providing voluntary home visitation for families with young children based on evidence-based models. The home visitation program must adhere to evidence-based models that have shown positive effects on child and parenting outcomes, employ well-trained staff, and demonstrate strong organizational capacity. The home visitation program must adhere to evidence-based models with positive effects on child and parenting outcomes, well-trained staff, and strong organizational capacity. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence. This includes expenditures for training, technical assistance, and evaluations related to the programs. Expenditures exceeding the applicable percentage of the State's allotment for the fiscal year are not eligible for a home visitation model with the strongest evidence of effectiveness. The applicable percentage is 60 percent for fiscal year 2010. The State's allotment for fiscal years 2010-2014 ranges from 60% to 40%. States cannot use other federal funds for the state match. The Secretary has waiver authority to modify requirements. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify provisions of the section for Indian tribes if it would impose an undue burden. Indian tribes can meet certain requirements if the Secretary waives or modifies them. Each State receiving a grant must submit reports. Each State receiving a grant under this section must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the services provided, program characteristics, and provider qualifications. The annual report must include information on program services, recipients' characteristics, costs, outcomes, and training provided for program implementation. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, and development. The evaluation will be conducted independently to monitor program effectiveness. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess their impact on child maltreatment, health, development, school readiness, and links to community services. The effectiveness of these programs on different populations will be examined, with an interim report to Congress due within 2 years of enactment. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress within 4 years on the evaluation of home visitation programs. Additionally, annual reports on activities funded under this section, including programs targeting high-need communities, will be submitted to Congress. The final report to Congress will include details on the service delivery models, program characteristics, outcomes, and research-based instruction used in home visitation programs funded under this section. The final report to Congress will include details on the service delivery models, program characteristics, outcomes, and research-based instruction used in home visitation programs funded under this section. The report will also cover the training, costs, monitoring indicators, and reservations of funds for the programs. The Secretary is appropriated $10,000,000 for evaluation, training, and technical assistance for early childhood home visitation programs, with an additional 3 percent for grants to Indian tribes. Additionally, $100,000,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2010 to carry out this section. The Secretary is allocated funding for early childhood home visitation programs as follows: $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $250,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $400,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, $550,000,000 for fiscal year 2013, and $700,000,000 for fiscal year 2014. Indian Tribes are treated as States in this section.
